Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 1: A Novel Machine Learning Framework for Urban Heat Island Causal Analysis: a Fusion of Observations and Physical Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The urban heat island is a phenomenon whereby urban areas have higher surface and atmospheric temperatures than surrounding suburban and rural regions. These higher temperatures lead to increases in building cooling energy use during summer, and can exacerbate urban air pollution, human thermal comfort, and heat waves. This project unites expertise in three fields---machine learning, civil and environmental engineering, and earth science---to develop a novel framework that integrates data-driven approaches and physics-based climate simulation models to better understand the physical process drivers of urban heat islands around the world. Better understanding the main drivers of urban heat islands in cities is critical for identifying the appropriate engineering solutions for mitigating urban warming from heat islands. This research will have broad societal impact by changing the ways that people participate in scientific data analysis tasks, and will build a stronger body of research in computational sustainability.

The proposed framework will integrate data-driven approaches and physically based models in one discovery process. It consists of three important steps: (i) latent feature discovery, which aims to automatically infer high-level feature representations from large scale observational data via deep networks. These latent features capture the complex nonlinear transformation of observed variables as a metaphor of latent physical processes; (ii) latent feature interpretation, which generates candidates of urban heat island drivers from the latent features via a compiled dataset. It provides insights into how these latent features are associated with physical processes; and (iii) urban heat island driver identification, which designs effective experiments to identify the causes of heat islands by varying observed variables from simulation models. The project is expected to advance the knowledge of key physical process drivers causing urban heat islands in cities. In addition, the developed framework has the potential to advance machine learning, including feature learning, causal analysis with confounders, and causal experiment design. The source code for computational tools and the data sets collected through the project will be freely disseminated to the broader research and educational community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change is one of the great sustainability challenges in our society.  An important problem in urban sustainability is the urban heat island (UHI) effect, a phenomenon whereby urban areas have higher surface and atmospheric temperatures than surrounding suburban and rural regions. These higher temperatures lead to increases in building cooling energy use during summer, can negatively impact outdoor human thermal comfort, and can exacerbate urban air pollution and heat waves.

 

UHIs have been studied for decades, and are thought to be caused by urban versus rural differences in the land surface. However, past work has failed to agree on the dominant physical process drivers causing the UHI in cities around the globe, which is critical for identifying the best possible solutions for mitigating urban warming and adapting to the local impacts of global climate change. With vastly increasing observational and climate model data characterizing Earth?s atmosphere and land surface,  we developed one-of-a-kind framework that naturally integrates data-driven approaches and physics-based climate simulation models by uniting expertise in three distinctive fields, i.e., machine learning, civil and environmental engineering, and earth science. The project has resulted in 12 publications in top conferences and journals of both climate science and machine learning. Below we highlight some of the key activities and findings.

 

Hierarchical deep generative models for multi-rate data: The climate data collection usually consists of multi-rate multivariate time series. To address this challenge, we developed the Multi-Rate Hierarchical Deep Markov Model (MR-HDMM), a novel deep generative model which uses the latent hierarchical structure with a learnable switch mechanism to effectively capture the temporal dependencies of multi-rate multivariate time series.

 

Interpreting neural networks: We developed a framework, namely Neural Interaction Transparency (NIT), that disentangles the shared learning across different interactions to obtain their intrinsic lower-order and interpretable structure. This work is significantly important to discover correct causal relations in meteorological behaviors.

 

Physic-informed machine learning model: While deep learning models have been very successful in data-rich areas, many conventional methods still have a prominent role to leverage specifically described domain knowledge such as physics equations. However, both data-driven methods and knowledge-based methods have their own drawbacks; it is hard to understand what the former model learns in data, whereas the latter is unlikely to learn undescribed rules. To fill this gap, we developed a novel architecture named Physics-aware Graph Neural Networks (PA-GNN) that automatically approximates the spatial derivatives of the graph signal and leverages data-driven end-to-end learning. PA-GNN is optimized to process graph-structured data, which are very common in climate observations.

 

Causal discovery from deep models: One of our goals is to discover attributions leading temperature variations from climate observations that can be extended to understanding of the urban heat island effect (UHIE), which is particularly problematic along with the rapid expansion of urban regions recently. We developed a deep learning model formed with attention and convolutional networks to extract possible attributions and time lag mainly affecting temperature dynamics.

 

Relationships between observed temperatures and acquired land use/land cover datasets: We analyzed mobile transect measurements of air temperature, as well as fixed site personal weather stations. Statistical relationships between observed air temperatures and averaged land cover properties within 500m radius of the measurements were computed. The most important land surface indicators were found to be roof albedo and tree cover. We reported the first observational evidence that solar reflective cool roofs are associated with measurable air temperature reductions. 

 

Broader Impact: the models developed in this project are expected to be applicable to many areas with spatiotemporal data and systems involving physical simulation models. The KDD workshop on "mining and learning from time series" was organized to disseminate the results of the project. Talks and tutorials were given to both academia and industry communities at the intersection of machine learning and climate. In addition, the research was presented to policy makers throughout the city and county of Los Angeles as part of the committee on cooling and urban heat impacts. The Committee on Cooling and Urban Heat Impacts is made up of mostly policy makers from various entities of the city and county of Los Angeles (including the LA Mayor's Office). The goal of the committee is to create appropriate policies to promote reducing temperatures in Los Angeles via smart land use decisions. The co-PI also assisted the LA Mayor's Office of Sustainability with their goals to reduce the urban heat island effect in Los Angeles.
